intro: Xyris vaupesana, commonly known as the golden cupflower, is a flowering plant native to the wetlands and marshes of South America. It belongs to the Xyridaceae family and is characterized by its bright yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows up to 60 cm tall, with narrow, grass-like leaves and a dense cluster of flowers at the top. Xyris vaupesana thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in swamps and along riverbanks. It plays an important role in supporting local pollinators and maintaining wetland ecosystems.
